title: Elle Macpherson - intimate and inscrutable
text:
As a kid growing up in Sydney's East Lindfield, she says she was an OK student who loved art and English. School for her was nothing like it is for her sons, 21-year-old Flynn and 16-year-old Cy, whose father is French financier Arpad Busson. “You just sort of went to school and came home and did your homework, or maybe you didn’t.” She played netball, goal attack, “because I was tall and liked to shoot goals and run around”, and swam, which she loved.

“I would get up at 5am every day and do my training and that was really important to me. It’s been the foundation of my discipline as far as being camera-ready.” I ask her about the rumour that she used to do 1000 sit-ups daily. “I think at one point I did,” she says. “Because it was what I thought was necessary to be professional.” Now, her understanding of wellness has changed, she says, and is about consciously nourishing herself rather than doing the same thing over and over and expecting different results.

Macpherson with then husband Arki Busson in 2002. AP

It’s an excellent segue into her latest business venture, the five-year-old “third child”, WelleCo, a supplement line she co-founded with former friend Andrea Horwood. It’s the holy grail of businesses, she says, because she gets to do what she loves, make a profit and make a difference in people’s lives, in much the same way her life was transformed when she “discovered” a plant-based diet and began taking the supplements that would one day become WelleCo’s line of powdered greens and so-called superfoods. Recently the company has suffered a blow: Macpherson and Horwood have parted ways, with Horwood alleging that Macpherson and other investors deliberately cut her out of the $21 million business.

Macpherson can’t comment since Horwood is suing Rolico, WelleCo’s parent company. “Business is a journey,” Macpherson says, “Sometimes things fall together and sometimes they fall apart. Things evolve.” She requests that we move on.

Macpherson never set out to be a model. She was going to study law, she can’t remember where, but thinks it was probably Macquarie University, and realised she would need to finance the study herself. “I worked in a pharmacy when I was 13, then I was a waitress. I was very comfortable working to earn a living.” A friend suggested modelling and she thought, “Why not? Let’s give it a go.” It’s a refrain Macpherson repeats often during our conversation, and something she sees as the Australian way. “It’s very Aussie, you know, that attitude of get up and get on with things. Australians are very courageous. We like giving things a go.”

Macpherson struck gold in a commercial for Tab cola, in which she appeared in a red bikini that mirrored the soda’s can. At the end of a “gap year” of modelling, she got the chance to go to New York with an agency. “Originally it was for a few weeks, then it was a few months and … that was 37 years ago.” New York in the early 1980s was rough and ready, she says; she felt nervous at night. She hung out with a band of artists and musicians and felt like she was part of a cultural hub. “I was very blessed,” she says. She doesn't regret skipping law. "I still get to read lots of contracts!"

Macpherson scans the menu, mentioning that she “loves vegetables”, and settles on ratatouille, checking with the waiter that there is no meat in the dish and that the bread comes on the side (it does). I’m tempted to eat steak frites in front of the supermodel but deep down I know I’ll never do it; I choose the nicoise salad and am too afraid even to eat the croutons it comes with.

Would Macpherson like a drink? It’s Friday, after all.

“I don’t drink.”

Advertisement

Oh. “When did you stop?”

Macpherson graced five Sports Illustrated covers – more than any other model.

“Sixteen years ago.”

“Any particular reason?”

“Because I decided to stop drinking.”

“Was it hard?”

“No. It was just a decision.”

“Do you feel better for it?”

“What kind of a question is that? Bit leading.” She pauses, looking down at the table in front of her. “No, I just don’t miss it.”

Ah. “Did you drink a lot before?”

Advertisement

“We’re not going there.”

We move on once more. In 1986, the then 21-year-old Macpherson married French photographer Gilles Bensimon, who was 42 at the time.

This is one of Macpherson's favourite images ever.

He was creative director for the French edition of Elle magazine and they worked together; she learnt what made a good image, how to navigate the fashion industry. “One of my favourite images ever is one that Gilles did for Elle. I had wet hair, a fringe, my hair was dark and I had fluorescent zinc on my nose. It was very surfer, very Australian, but something about the way Gilles did it, he made me look like a warrior, like it was war paint.” Though they divorced in 1989, the pair remain close. In May this year, she posted a series of images he’d taken of her in the '80s to Instagram to celebrate their wedding anniversary, even though they haven't been together for 30 years. “We speak every week,” she says matter-of-factly. “We’ve always been close.” Was there a time, perhaps after their split, when they didn’t speak? She shakes her head. “No.”

Our salads arrive and Macpherson takes her plate into her hands, looking down into it. At first I think she is speaking to me as she says, “Thank you, universe, for this beautiful food. I am so blessed to be here sharing with you.” I start to answer her before I realise that she hasn’t finished. “Thank you for giving me your time today. Thank you for this magnificent food which Mother Earth has provided for us.”

I’m not sure how to answer except to ask if Macpherson is a spiritual person. Yes, she says. “I consider myself to have a strong spiritual foundation.” She eats (but only half of what's on her plate).

How did she move from modelling to business? In the early '90s, supermodels were big business themselves – Linda Evangelista, it was said, refused to get up for less than $10,000 a day – but without the associated brand extensions they now have. Elizabeth Taylor was shilling perfumes but there was no Kylie Jenner with her billion-dollar lip kits or Miranda Kerr selling organic skincare.

“I took a risk,” she says. “Necessity is the mother of invention. I wanted to evolve out of being in front of the camera to a position where I’d seen a lot of sportspeople succeed, people like Greg Norman and John Newcombe.” At the time, Norman had licensed his name to a line of Nike sneakers. Macpherson thought she could do the same and went into business with New Zealand corset-maker Bendon, manufacturing a line of lingerie with her name attached. In 2005, Vanity Fair reported that the range raked in more than $70 million in sales across Asia, Australia, New Zealand and the UK. When it launched in the US that year, Macpherson’s good friend Gwyneth Paltrow gave the maternity bra her tick of approval on The Oprah Winfrey Show. Not a bad endorsement.

Macpherson in 1998 with models dressed in her eponymous underwear range.

Still, at first Macpherson wasn’t sure it would work, and even now she says the success was more about being in the right place at the right time. “It wasn’t like I could say, here’s another model who’s done this, let’s emulate what she’s done. It was an intuitive move. I made choices because they felt right. There was no great intellect to it.”

Advertisement

Her father, Peter Gow, owned a chain of electronics stores, Miranda Hi-Fi, and Macpherson considers him her business mentor. “He was self-made, resourceful, creative. He gave me an indication of what it would be like to be my own boss.”

“I took a risk. Necessity is the mother of invention," says Macpherson. Janie Barrett

Other licensing opportunities didn’t quite hit the mark for Macpherson; she turned down a Barbie doll made in her likeness, for example. “Oh my gosh, I’d forgotten about that,” she says. “I probably had some feeling about it, you know, objectifying women.”

She sometimes feels misunderstood and says she is misquoted, like the time in 1992 when she reportedly told Good Weekend that she'd never read anything she hadn't written herself.

"That's actually a misquote," she says. "As if I was going to say that! I don't even understand how they misconstrued it." Surely, she adds, people are smart enough to understand that the quote was a total fallacy.

Macpherson dabbled in acting, too, appearing in six episodes of Friends and before that, securing a two-year deal with Miramax. What was her experience with Harvey Weinstein? “We made great projects together,” she says. She counts them off on her fingers: “Sirens, my workout videos, a film called Jane Eyre.” She looks me in the eye as she says, “My dealings with him were very professional and, actually, very good experiences.”

“Really?”

“Yeah.”

“You might be the only woman in Hollywood who can say that.”

Advertisement

She shrugs and throws her hands in the air, saying nothing.

And this is the thing about Macpherson: you think you’re getting somewhere, and then the wall goes up again, the defences raised. There is no penetrating those barriers. I tell her that Bob Hawke had a portrait of the two of them in his office when he was prime minister and she says, “You’re kidding!” She remembers taking the photo with him but says only, and dryly, “Yeah, it was at the peak of both of our careers.”

I ask her how she’d like to be remembered: as a model, as a businesswoman, as an icon? And finally she allows a crack in the veneer. “As Flynn and Cy’s mum,” she says. “If that’s all I ever did, I’d be very happy indeed.”

The bill

Sofitel Darling Harbour, 12 Darling Drive, Sydney

Ratatouille, $25

Nicoise salad, $22

2 espressos, $8

1 bottle sparkling water, $9

Total $64
description: Over Lunch with the AFR, the former supermodel talks about business break-ups, Harvey Weinstein and being misquoted.
